question: Which statement correctly describes the trend in atomic radius across Period 3 from sodium to argon?
options: Atomic radius increases because more electrons are added to the same shell
Atomic radius decreases because the charge of the nucleus increases while electrons are in the same shell
Atomic radius increases because the atoms become heavier
Atomic radius remains constant because the number of electron shells does not change
answer: Atomic radius decreases because the charge of the nucleus increases while electrons are in the same shell

question: Why does atomic radius increase down Group 1 from lithium to cesium?
options: The charge of the nucleus decreases down the group
More electron shells are added, so the outer electrons are further from the nucleus
Electrons are removed from the outer shell, reducing repulsion
The attraction from the nucleus experienced by outer electrons increases
answer: More electron shells are added, so the outer electrons are further from the nucleus

question: Ionisation energy is the energy required to remove one electron from each atom in one mole of gaseous atoms. Why does this energy generally increase across Period 2 from lithium to neon?
options: Atoms become heavier across the period
The charge of the nucleus increases while electrons are in the same shell, so the attraction is stronger
Atomic radius increases, so outer electrons are held more tightly
More electron shells are added, increasing the energy needed
answer: The charge of the nucleus increases while electrons are in the same shell, so the attraction is stronger

question: Ionisation energy is the energy required to remove one electron from each atom in one mole of gaseous atoms. Why does this energy decrease down Group 17 from fluorine to iodine?
options: The charge of the nucleus decreases down the group
Outer electrons are in shells further from the nucleus, so the attraction is weaker
Atomic radius decreases, making electron removal easier
The attraction from the nucleus experienced by outer electrons increases significantly
answer: Outer electrons are in shells further from the nucleus, so the attraction is weaker

question: Electronegativity is a measure of how strongly an atom attracts electrons when it is bonded to another atom. Which element has the highest electronegativity?
options: Sodium
Aluminium
Chlorine
Argon

question: Electronegativity is a measure of how strongly an atom attracts electrons when it is bonded to another atom. Why does electronegativity generally increase across Period 3 from sodium to chlorine?
options: Atoms become heavier across the period
The charge of the nucleus increases while electrons are in the same shell, so the attraction for bonding electrons is stronger
Atomic radius increases, so bonding electrons are held more tightly
More electron shells are added, increasing the attraction for electrons
answer: The charge of the nucleus increases while electrons are in the same shell, so the attraction for bonding electrons is stronger

question: Electronegativity is a measure of how strongly an atom attracts electrons when it is bonded to another atom. Why does electronegativity decrease down Group 17 from fluorine to iodine?
options: The charge of the nucleus decreases down the group
Bonding electrons are in shells further from the nucleus, so the attraction is weaker
Atomic radius decreases, making electron attraction easier
The attraction from the nucleus experienced by bonding electrons increases significantly
answer: Bonding electrons are in shells further from the nucleus, so the attraction is weaker

question: Element X is in Period 3, Group 16. Element Y is in Period 4, Group 16. Ionisation energy is the energy required to remove one electron from each atom in one mole of gaseous atoms. Electronegativity is a measure of how strongly an atom attracts electrons when bonded. Which statement correctly compares X and Y?
options: Y has a smaller atomic radius, higher ionisation energy and higher electronegativity than X
Y has a larger atomic radius, lower ionisation energy and lower electronegativity than X
X and Y have the same atomic radius because they are in the same group
X has lower ionisation energy and lower electronegativity because it has fewer protons
answer: Y has a larger atomic radius, lower ionisation energy and lower electronegativity than X
